>contaminating a jury pool
How can you contaminate a jury pool by quoting the law and the constitution? Prosecutors don't like the idea that you know about jury nullification, but it's just a fancy name for the logical consequence of the jury's verdict being de-jure correct. If there could be a "wrong" verdict there'd be no need for a jury because the judge would determine what the correct verdict was and the jury would have to return to the same correct verdict or be in contempt of court. Ergo there can be no such thing as a "wrong verdict", so jury nullification is de-jure legal, and talking about it is merely mentioning true facts about the law.

posts.com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

You were doing so well.

The winning conditions are in an array so you can use a nested loop (or some kind of lambda function) to test them all without writing a bunch of repetitive code

function testVictoryCondition(c, b) { //Condition, Board
p = "" // see note
for i in c {
if (p == "") { p = b[c]; continue;}
if (b[c] != p) return false; }
return p // this will be false if the whole line is full of empty squares, assuming empty squares are falsy}

function testAllVictoryConditions (C, b) {
for c in C { if (winner=testVictoryCondition(c,b)) {declareWinner(winner);}}
// no winner :(
}


* note: this is a common problem with for-loop patterns: you want to do something different for the first iteration to set everything up, but you can't do it outside the loop because the variables are only in-scope inside the loop. Checking if you're initialised or not is one solution; every solution is kinda bad.

If verbosely using the 8 if-statements is not mandatory, here is a more compact way to check for a win:

function isWin() {
return winningCondition.some(
(condition) => {
let line = condition.map((idx)=>document.getElementById(boardIndex[idx]).textContent);
return (line[0] != "" && line.every((x)=>x==line[0]))
}
)
}

To check if there is a draw, keep track of the amount of turns. Nine turns without a win is a draw.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1294263
>-tor
Brave's manual doesn't list this one at all, but wouldn't it be "--tor"?
Unix convention is one minus for single-letter arguments ("-o", "-t", "-v") and two minuses for multiple-letter arguments ("--sparse", "--verbose"), and a lot of the command-line parsing libraries make doing anything else difficult or impossible.

1. How many ways can the digits from 0 to 9 be written in a row so that the even digits go in ascending order and the odd ones in descending order?

3. How many partial orders are there on an n-element set in which exactly one pair of elements is incomparable?

4. A partition of a set $A$ is such a family of its subsets that each element of $A$ is included in exactly one subset of the family. posts.com:
I have a small tplink LS1005G, and I cant connect almost anything on it, but a laptop with the r8168 driver refuses to work at all, checked cables, changed cables, make a manually configuration, copy the values from another working machine with the same configuration.
The same machines worked fine before.

The usual setup was
PC1----------------------|
PC2----------------------|
MODEM/ROUTER...|-------------------LS1005G
or
PC1----------------------|
PC2----------------------|-------------------LS1005G

any of the former worked out, so I don'k know
why it changed and it does make his job,
Thanks anon!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1293798
>LS1005G
You probably have a cable with a damaged pair, so the switch and the NIC think they can do gigabit (which uses all four pairs), but then it doesn't work.

Try a brand-new cable, or force the driver to not autonegotiate but instead select 100 Base TX (which uses only two pairs).
